SEARCH
Package gw.api.util.calendar

Interface PublicBusinessCalendarWorker

public interface PublicBusinessCalendarWorker
Represents a business calendar, often targetted for a particular area such as a zone or location (though there may also be default workers that apply more generally).

BusinessCalendarWorkers are intended to be used briefly by a single thread and then discarded. They are not thread safe and may not remain valid over a long period of time - for example they may depend on data saved in the database that can change over time.

Author:
akeefer, bchang

  • Method Details

    • isDuringBusinessHours

      boolean isDuringBusinessHours(Date time)
      Indicates whether or not this date is during business hours, i.e. between the start of the business day and the end of the business day on a business day.
      Parameters:
      time - the date to check
      Returns:
      true if the date is during business hours, false if it's on a non-business day or not during business hours

    • isBusinessDay

      boolean isBusinessDay(Date date)
      Indicates whether or not the given date represents a business day. Only the date is checked, i.e. the hour, minute, and second are ignored. It must be a weekday and not a holiday.
      Parameters:
      date - the date to check
      Returns:
      true if the date is a business day, false otherwise

    • elapsedBusinessTime

      long elapsedBusinessTime(Date start, Date end)
      Returns the number of milliseconds of business time that have elapsed between the start and end dates.
      Parameters:
      start - the start time
      end - the end time
      Returns:
      the number of milliseconds of business time between start and end

    • getStartBusinessDay

      Date getStartBusinessDay(Date date)
      Returns the start of the current business day, defined as the end of the last business day (so a business day might occupy more than 24 hours, such as for Monday).
      Returns:
      the start of the current business day

    • getStartCurrentBusinessDay

      Date getStartCurrentBusinessDay()

    • getStartBusinessWeek

      Date getStartBusinessWeek(Date date)
      Returns the start of the current business week, which is the same as the end of the last business week. Normally a business week ends on a specified day, but in the even that that day is a holiday, the start of the business week wraps backwords to the end of the last business day before that date.
      Returns:
      the time that the current business week started

    • getStartCurrentBusinessWeek

      Date getStartCurrentBusinessWeek()

    • getEndBusinessDay

      Date getEndBusinessDay(Date date)
      Returns the end of the current business day, defined as the specified end time on the current day, if this is a business day, or if we're after closing or its a holiday, the end of the day on the next business day.
      Returns:
      the end of the current business day

    • getEndCurrentBusinessDay

      Date getEndCurrentBusinessDay()

    • getEndBusinessWeek

      Date getEndBusinessWeek(Date date)
      Computes the end of the current business week. Normally, this is simply the end of the day on the last day of the week. If that day's a holiday, however, we find the last business day before that day but after today. If today and all days after it this week are holidays, then we wind forward to look for the end of the next business day in a week that isn't entirely holidays.
      Returns:
      the end of the current business week

    • getEndCurrentBusinessWeek

      Date getEndCurrentBusinessWeek()

    • isDuringBusinessWeek

      boolean isDuringBusinessWeek(Date week, Date date)
      Indicates whether or not this time is between the end of the last business week and the start of the next business week.

      boolean isDuringCurrentBusinessWeek(Date date)

    • isDuringBusinessDay

      boolean isDuringBusinessDay(Date day, Date date)
      Indicates whether or not this time is between the end of the last business day and the end of the next/current business day.
      Parameters:
      day - the business day
      date - the date to test
      Returns:
      true if date is within the business day that day belongs to

    • addDays

      Date addDays(Date date, int nDays)
      Adds nDays business days to the given date. The hours, minutes, and seconds remain the same.
      Parameters:
      date - the date to which to add
      nDays - the number of business days to add
      Returns:
      the date nDays business days after the given date

    • addHours

      Date addHours(Date date, int nHours)

    • differenceDays

      int differenceDays(Date fromDate, Date toDate)
      Subtracts toDate from fromDate to give the difference in business days (i.e. toDate - fromDate). If toDate is after fromDate, the result will be a positive number. If toDate is before fromDate, the result will be negative.

      In other words, this returns the number of business days between fromDate and toDate, including toDate and not including fromDate.

      addDays() and differenceDays should cancel out. That is, for two dates date1 and date2, which are apart by nDays business days, the following should hold true: addDays(date1, nDays) == date2 differenceDays(date1, date2) == nDays NOTE: The times of day in the Dates are ignored in the calculation.

      Parameters:
      fromDate - the right operand in the subtraction
      toDate - the left operand in the subtraction
      Returns:
      the difference in business days

    • differenceHours

      int differenceHours(Date fromDate, Date toDate)

    • roundToNearestBusinessHour

      Date roundToNearestBusinessHour(Date date, PublicBusinessCalendarWorker.Direction dir)
      Given a date object, if the time is outside business hours, return the nearest business hour on that business day. In the case that the calculated date falls on a holiday, then we will round to the start of the next business day if direction is FORWARD, or to the end of the previous business day if direction is BACKWARD. If time is already within business hours, then a copy of the original date object is returned.
      Parameters:
      date - Date object containing the time
      dir - Direction in which to round
      Returns:
      A new instance of Date object that is properly rounded
